unnormalised: My grandfather, Shri. R.K. Sharma, always held a certain mystique for me. Growing up in a small town in Uttar Pradesh, I knew him primarily as the stern but loving patriarch, the one who always had a story ready or a piece of advice, whether I wanted it or not. It wasn’t until I was much older that I truly understood the weight of his former role.
normalised: My grandfather, Shri R.K. Sharma, always held a certain mystique for me. Growing up in a small town in Uttar Pradesh, I knew him primarily as the stern but loving patriarch, the one who always had a story ready or a piece of advice, whether I wanted it or not. It wasn't until I was much older that I truly understood the weight of his former role.

unnormalised: He’d often mention things like "when I was a DM" or "during my time in the IAS," but these were just phrases to my young ears, lost amongst tales of mischievous monkeys and summer mangoes. All I really knew was that he’d worked for the government, a fact that seemed rather unremarkable compared to the Bollywood heroes I idolized.
normalised: He'd often mention things like "when I was a D-M" or "during my time in the I-A-S," but these were just phrases to my young ears, lost amongst tales of mischievous monkeys and summer mangoes. All I really knew was that he'd worked for the government, a fact that seemed rather unremarkable compared to the Bollywood heroes I idolized.

unnormalised: It was during a school project about local governance that I finally began to piece things together. I asked my mother about Grandfather’s job, and she pulled out an old photo album. There he was, a younger version of the man I knew, shaking hands with dignitaries, reviewing files, and generally exuding an air of quiet authority. The caption read: "District Magistrate, Varanasi, 1978-1982." The term "DM" suddenly clicked.
normalised: It was during a school project about local governance that I finally began to piece things together. I asked my mother about Grandfather's job, and she pulled out an old photo album. There he was, a younger version of the man I knew, shaking hands with dignitaries, reviewing files, and generally exuding an air of quiet authority. The caption read: "District Magistrate, Varanasi, nineteen seventy eight to nineteen eighty two." The term "D-M" suddenly clicked.

unnormalised: My mother explained that he had started as an IAS officer after clearing the civil services exam in the early 1960s. He had worked his way up through the ranks, holding various positions like SDM (Sub-Divisional Magistrate) in different districts before eventually becoming a District Magistrate. This was a big deal, she emphasized, practically the king of the district. The responsibility was immense, and so was the respect.
normalised: My mother explained that he had started as an I-A-S officer after clearing the civil services exam in the early nineteen sixties. He had worked his way up through the ranks, holding various positions like S-D-M (Sub-Divisional Magistrate) in different districts before eventually becoming a District Magistrate. This was a big deal, she emphasized, practically the king of the district. The responsibility was immense, and so was the respect.

unnormalised: She showed me old letters addressed to "The District Magistrate, Varanasi," some seeking favors, others lodging complaints, and still others simply seeking guidance. He was the final authority on everything from law and order to land disputes to agricultural policies. He oversaw elections, managed crises, and was responsible for the well-being of millions of people.

unnormalised: I learned that he had also served as the Secretary of several government departments after his stint as DM, a position he held until his retirement. The bureaucracy seemed incredibly complex and hierarchical, with officers like him at the helm, navigating the intricate web of rules and regulations. My mother also shared that he was once offered the role of Chief Secretary of the state, but he declined due to his failing health.

unnormalised: Suddenly, his stories took on a new meaning. The anecdotes about dealing with unruly politicians, mediating conflicts between communities, and implementing government schemes weren't just stories; they were glimpses into a world of power, responsibility, and often, immense pressure. It was a world far removed from my own, yet intimately connected to the smooth functioning of the society I lived in.

unnormalised: Now, when I visit my grandfather, I listen with a different ear. The casual mentions of his time as "Addl. Secy." or his interactions with the "CM" are no longer just background noise. They are fragments of a life dedicated to public service, a life that shaped the course of countless others, and a life that continues to inspire me to understand the complex machinery of our government and the crucial role played by individuals like Shri. R.K. Sharma.
